div.head: Preface
div.p: The text of the rubrics for 4.6.1 and 4.6.2 is quite similar in all four R1 mss., and substantially different from the readings reported in Fr. 4.6.1: "Qui in accusatione episcopi culpabilis inuenitur ad arguendum de cetero non admittatur nisi propriam causam ciuilem solummodo asserere uoluerit" in Aa Bc Fd P, and "In ciuili et proprio dumtaxat negotio ad arguendum admittitur, qui in episcopi accusatione culpabilis inuenitur" in Fr. 4.6.2: "Non negatur audientia in propria causa cuius accusatio interdicitur" in Aa Bc Fd P, and "Propriam causam agere ualet cui accusare non licet" in Fr.
C.4 q.2-3 d.p.c.3 quotes a cryptic statement, not found in Clavis Canonum, attributed to St. Brice (†.444), a controversial disciple of St. Martin, and his successor as bishop of Tours.

The most interesting text in the case is Gratian's one and only dictum, C.4 q.2-3 d.p.c.3. "Set obicitur illud beati Bricii, qui uoce pueri xxx dies ab ortu habentis innocens probatus est. Set miracula diuina sunt admiranda, non in exemplum humane actionis trahenda." The Latin of the first sentence is somewhat opaque. Taking the accusative plural dies as the object of habentis, and supplying exemplum because it is neuter and can be construed with illud, the sentence can be literally translated as "But that [example] of blessed Brice is objected, who was proved innocent by the voice of the child having thirty days from its birth or origin." The dictum can be translated into more idiomatic English as "But a counter-example is that of St. Brice, who was proved innocent by the word of a thirty-day-old child. But divine miracles are to be wondered at, not to be taken as a pattern for human action."

Gratian is referring to a story from Gregory of Tours, History of the Franks, II.1, about St. Brice (†.444), St. Martin's controversial immediate successor as bishop of Tours. This is the only mention of Brice in the Decretum, and History of the Franks falls outside what we normally consider to be the boundaries of Gratian's formal or material sources. (Friedberg attributes the story to the Life of St. Martin by Sulpicius Severus, although he really seems to have had in mind an unrelated story from the third book of Sulpicius's Dialogues in which Marin compares Brice to Judas. In any event Friedberg was wrong, the proper attribution is to Gregory.) Gregory relates the story of a nun or consecrated virgin serving as a laundress for Brice's episcopal household who became pregnant and delivered a child. The people of Tours, with whom Brice was already quite unpopular, suspected that he was the father. Brice had the thirty-day-old infant brought to him, and questioned the child publicly concerning his paternity. Through the saint's miraculous intervention, the child spoke plainly, answering that Brice was not its father.

The dictum is relevant in its immediate context, since Gratian is concluding his treatment of the second question, whether someone under the age of fourteen is able to testify in a criminal case. But Gratian's reference to this obscure story also seems intended to caution against depending on miracles as a regular part of criminal procedure, and by extension implies a negative judgement on the validity of trial by ordeal.

p.note: "It is remarkable that in his dicta Gratian refers to sources that are not cited in the Decretum. Many biblical citations, for example, are found only in the dicta. They are often tied to important theological reflections ..." (Landau, "Gratian and the Decretum Gratiani", 41.)

div.p: There are two marginal glosses in the Aa text of C.4 that refer to Burchard's Decretum: "B.xvi. Nemo ſimul ſit." (Burchard 16.15) at 4.4.1, and "B.i. Qͥſqͥs." (Burchard 1.160) at 4.6.1. A rubric in between C.4 and C.5 ("Explicit liber quintus, incipit liber sextus, de episcoporum accusationibus") indicates a non-standard division of Aa into books.

The order of rubrics in C.4 q.4 is reversed in Bc. The rubric for 4.4.2 ("Quilibet in causa duas personas gerere non valet") appears before 4.4.1, and the rubric for 4.4.1 ("Accusator, testis vel iudex aliquis simul esse non potest") appears before 4.4.2. Bc includes two canons — 4.6.3 and 4.6.4 — not listed in Winroth's appendix and not found in either Aa or P.
The quality of scribal workmanship in P is visibly less professional than that in either Aa or Bc.

In addition to scribal errors, Aa, Bc, and P reflect divergence from Classical Latin orthography for ci and ti. Aa: spacium; Bc: defitiens, iuditio and iuditium, and prouintie; and P: accionis, audiencia, and tercio.

div.head: (C.4 d.init.)
div.ab: An excommunicate undertook to accuse a bishop. He brought a person under the age of 14 to support his case. [assertio was originally used to mean the defense of a person’s character. In the middle ages the word took on a modern meaning of assertion. It retained its positive meaning—i.e. it was a statement in favor of something. Here, I think it means that the accuser brought the young person in to support his accusation against the bishop.] Prohibited from making the accusation [because he was an excommunicate], he made [introduced, assigned] the adolescent the accuser and himself the witness. [In other words, the excommunicate switched roles with the youth, but the next sentence raises a question about the meaning of se here.] The adolescent began to act as accuser and witness. On the appointed day, the bishop did not agree [minime concurrit] to come before the electors’ [those chosen to be judges] court. He was suspended from communion. Finally, the court having been reconvened, the accuser [I believe this refers to the youth] was found culpable in making the accusation. In the end, he [I believe this person is the original accuser, the excommunicate] proceeded to make his case.
